definition:
Let $G$ be a topological group. A *unitary representation* of $G$ is a
pair $(\pi, H)$ where $H$ is a Hilbert space and $\pi: G \to U(H)$ is a
homomorphism such that the mapping of $G \times H \to H$ that sends
$(g,v)$ to $\pi(g)v$ is continuous. Here $U(H)$ denotes the set of
unitary operators of $H$. The group $G$ is said to act unitarily on $H$
or sometimes, $G$ is said to act by unitary representation on $H$.
